content: The "Appalachian Regional Development Act Amendments of 2008" limits the available amounts and maximum commission contribution for grants and other assistance under Section 14321(a) of title 40, United States Code. The "Appalachian Regional Development Act Amendments of 2008" limits the commission's contribution for grants to local development districts for administrative expenses, ranging from 50% to 75% based on certain criteria. The grant is for a local development district with economic development authority in at-risk counties, covering 70% of administrative expenses. In general, financial assistance for eligible activities under this section can cover up to 50% of costs from appropriated funds, or up to 80% in distressed counties. Section 14502 of title 40, United States Code, is amended to include limitations on available amounts for grants under this section. Financial assistance can cover up to 50% of costs from appropriated funds, or up to 80% in distressed counties. In at-risk counties, 70% of funding may be provided from appropriated amounts. Financial assistance for the operation of a demonstration health project can cover up to 50% of the cost, or 80% in distressed counties. Financial assistance for a demonstration health project can cover up to 80% of the cost in distressed counties under section 14526. The maximum Commission contribution for projects in at-risk counties may be increased under certain conditions. Financial assistance for projects in at-risk counties can be increased to 70% or the maximum Federal contribution percentage. Section 14503 of title 40, United States Code, is amended to include limitations on available amounts for planning and financing low- and middle-income housing projects. Financial assistance for low- and middle-income housing projects can cover up to 50-80% of planning and financing costs, including surveys, architectural fees, and legal fees. In distressed counties, the assistance can go up to 80% of the costs. In distressed counties, financial assistance can cover up to 80% of planning and financing costs for low- and middle-income housing projects. The Secretary may provide financial assistance for housing projects in distressed counties, covering up to 80% of expenses that are unrecoverable from a permanent loan. The assistance cannot be given to for-profit organizations. The Telecommunications and Technology Initiative under title 40, United States Code, has a limitation on available amounts for grants, with not more than 50 percent of the cost provided from appropriated funds. In at-risk counties, the limit is 70 percent of expenses for projects. The Telecommunications and Technology Initiative in title 40, United States Code limits grants to 50 percent of costs from appropriated funds. In distressed counties, the limit is 80 percent, and in at-risk counties, it is 70 percent. Section 14505 is amended to remove subsection (c) and introduce new provisions. Section 14505 of title 40, United States Code is amended to limit the amount of grant funding available for entrepreneurship initiatives. The amendment specifies that 50 percent of costs can be provided from appropriated funds, with higher percentages allowed for distressed counties. Section 14526 allows for 80 percent funding from appropriated amounts, or 70 percent for at-risk counties. Section 14506 limits grant funding to 50 percent of costs from appropriated funds. Under this section, grant funding can be provided as follows: 50 percent from appropriated amounts, 80 percent for distressed counties, and 70 percent for at-risk counties. Section 14507(g) of title 40, United States Code is amended to increase the maximum Commission contribution for projects in at-risk counties to 70 percent. This is part of the Economic and Energy Development Initiative in chapter 145 of subtitle IV. The Appalachian Regional Commission may provide assistance for projects promoting energy efficiency and renewable energy resources in the Appalachian region to enhance economic competitiveness. The Appalachian Regional Commission aims to enhance economic competitiveness in the region by increasing the use of renewable energy resources, particularly biomass, for alternative transportation fuels, electricity, and heat. Additionally, the commission supports the development of regional energy resources through advanced technologies to reduce emissions, including greenhouse gases. Grants under this section may be provided up to 50% of appropriated amounts, with higher percentages for distressed or at-risk counties. Grants under this section may be provided up to 70 percent from appropriated amounts, in combination with other Federal programs or any other source. TERMINATION. Section 14704 of title 40, United States Code, is amended by changing the termination year from "2007" to "2012". SEC. 7. ADDITIONS TO APPALACHIAN REGION. Kentucky, Ohio, and Tennessee are amended to include additional counties in the Appalachian region. Kentucky adds Metcalfe, Nicholas, and Robertson. Ohio adds Ashtabula, Mahoning, and Trumbull. Tennessee includes Lawrence and Lewis counties. Virginia also sees amendments with the addition of Henry after Grayson, and Patrick after Montgomery.
